questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to her primary care physician for advice on a health insurance plan. She works as a baker and owns a small bakery. The patient explains that she would like to have affordable monthly premiums but would be willing to make additional payments to be able to see providers outside her network. The patient notes that she would be comfortable with being referred to specialists by her primary care physician. Which of the following health insurance plans would be most appropriate?

choices.text: Preferred provider organization
Medicare
Medicaid
Exclusive provider organization
Point of service

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In preferred provider organizations, patients do not need to see a primary care physician before seeing a specialist. Because the insurance covers care delivered by out-of-network providers, monthly rates are generally very high. Additionally, patients are required to cover out-of-pocket costs for many aspects of care. Because this patient specifically mentioned she would like affordable monthly payments, a preferred provider organization would not be the appropriate recommendation for her.

B) INCORRECT:

Medicare is a federal social health care program that is available to all patients who are older than 65 years of age as well as select other groups who may be younger than 65 (e.g., individuals with end-stage renal disease or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis). This patient, however, is not eligible for the program, as she is too young and does not have a qualifying condition. Furthermore, Medicare is a health care program rather than a health insurance plan.

C) INCORRECT:

Medicaid is a federal social health care program that assists individuals with limited financial resources in accessing health care and medical treatment. It is not an insurance plan. This self-employed patient does not mention needing financial assistance to afford health care and is willing to pay for affordable monthly premiums as part of a health insurance plan.

D) INCORRECT:

In exclusive provider organizations, patients can see specialists without a referral from a primary care doctor. There is no coverage for visiting providers outside of the network. Other than in an emergency, seeing a provider outside of the patient's network means that the patients will have to pay the full cost of care themselves. Although monthly premiums are initially low for healthy patients, medical treatment for a serious illness that might develop later can be very costly.

E) CORRECT:

In a point of service plan, patients usually require a referral from their primary care physician for specialist care (a feature of health maintenance organizations), but they can see providers outside of the network (a feature of preferred provider organizations). Usually, patients have to pay extra fees to see providers outside of the network, which is aimed at keeping fixed monthly premiums moderate. The primary care physician still acts as the gatekeeper for access to specialists. Because this patient is self-employed and has a chronic medical condition, the point of service plan would best suit her needs.

See “Commercial health insurance plans” table.
questions.hint: This insurance plan combines features of a health maintenance organization and a preferred provider organization.

questions.text: Before starting a new job at a law firm, a 33-year-old woman speaks to a representative about the health insurance plan offered by the firm. The representative explains that treatment is provided by primary health care physicians who focus on preventive care. Patients require a referral by the primary care physician for specialist care inside the network; treatment by health care providers outside the network is only covered in the case of an emergency. When the prospective employee asks how prices are negotiated between the health insurance company and the health care providers, the physician explains that the health care providers get a fixed payment for each patient enrolled over a specific period of time, regardless of whether or not services are provided. This arrangement best describes which of the following health care payment models?

choices.text: Per diem payment
Bundled payment
Fee-for-service
Discounted fee-for-service
Capitation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a per diem payment model, a health care organization is compensated a fixed amount per patient per day for a specific care service provided, regardless of the actual costs involved for providing services for any particular patient. This payment model is often used for reimbursement of inpatient services. For example, a hospital and payer can negotiate a fixed per diem rate for most routine inpatient services (e.g., common medical and surgical conditions) based on the average daily cost of admission. This model does not reflect the scenario described, in which health care providers receive a fixed amount for each patient enrolled over a specific period of time, regardless of whether or not services are provided.

B) INCORRECT:

In a bundled payment model, a healthcare organization is compensated a fixed amount for all services provided for a clinically-defined episode of care (e.g., hip replacement, cholecystectomy). Payment is then distributed to the health care providers. This model does not reflect the scenario described, in which health care providers receive a fixed amount for each patient enrolled over a specific period of time, regardless of whether or not services are provided.

C) INCORRECT:

In a fee-for-service (FFS) payment model, health care providers are compensated for each individual service provided (e.g., individual laboratory tests, imaging studies, procedures). They are not paid a fixed amount for each patient enrolled over a specific period of time, regardless of the amount of care provided, as described in this case. The FFS payment model carries the risk that patients will be overtreated because compensation is based on the amount of service provided.

D) INCORRECT:

In a discounted fee-for-service (FFS) payment model, health care providers are compensated for each individual service provided (e.g., individual laboratory tests, imaging studies, procedures) based on a fixed payment schedule negotiated between the health care providers and the payers. They are not paid a fixed amount for each patient enrolled over a specific period of time, regardless of the amount of care provided, as described in this case. Preferred provider organizations often use a discounted FFS payment model. As in a traditional FFS payment model, a discounted FFS payment model carries the risk that patients will be overtreated because compensation is based on the amount of service provided. However, because discounted prices are predetermined by negotiations between health care providers and payers, the financial incentive to provide excess care is decreased.

E) CORRECT:

Capitation is a health care payment model in which health care providers receive a specified amount of compensation per patient during each payment period, regardless of the actual amount of health care utilized by the patient. Capitation incentivizes health care providers to promote efficient use of health care resources (e.g., cost-effective preventive health care to avoid larger downstream costs). Risks of capitation include provision of substandard care as a method of cost reduction and rejection of medically complex patients from patient panels by providers to reduce negative impacts on the ability to meet quality metrics.
questions.hint: Health maintenance organizations often use this payment model.

questions.text: Before starting a new job at a large health care organization, a 29-year-old physician speaks to a representative in the human resources department regarding the health care payment model used by the organization. When the physician asks how prices are negotiated between the health insurance company and the health care organization, the representative explains that the organization is compensated a fixed amount for each episode of care. The representative explains that the fixed amount is distributed among all health care providers that provided care for the patient for that specific episode. This arrangement best describes which of the following health care payment models?

choices.text: Per diem payment
Fee-for-service
Capitation
Value-based care (pay-for-performance)
Bundled payment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a per diem payment model, a health care organization is compensated a fixed amount per patient and per day of care for a specific care service provided, regardless of the actual costs involved in providing services for any particular patient. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization is compensated a fixed amount for the entire clinically defined episode of care. A per diem payment model is often used for the reimbursement of inpatient services and can provide a perverse incentive for prolonging the duration of hospital stay.

B) INCORRECT:

In a fee-for-service payment model, health care organizations are compensated for each individual service provided (e.g., individual laboratory tests, imaging studies, procedures). This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care that is then distributed among all the health care providers involved. A fee-for-service payment model can be a perverse incentive against efficiency and risks patients being overtreated because compensation is based on the quantity of services provided.

C) INCORRECT:

In a capitation payment model, health care providers receive a set amount of compensation per patient during each payment period, regardless of the actual amount of health care utilized by the patient. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care. Capitation incentivizes health care providers to promote efficient use of health care resources (e.g., cost-effective preventive health care to avoid larger downstream costs) and increases accountability and transparency through reporting of quality metrics. Risks of capitation include provision of substandard care as a method of cost reduction and rejection of medically complex patients from patient panels by providers to reduce negative impacts on the ability to meet quality metrics.

D) INCORRECT:

Value-based care or pay-for-performance (P4P) comprises payment models in which compensation also depends on the quality of care physicians provide. Although P4P uses the fee-for-service system, it includes financial incentives or disincentives that depend on the health care provider's performance, which is assessed through the analysis of metric-driven outcomes, clinical practices, and patient satisfaction. This model does not reflect the scenario described here, in which the organization receives a fixed amount for each clinically defined episode of care, irrespective of the quality of care provided.

E) CORRECT:

The arrangement describes a bundled payment model in which a health care organization is compensated a fixed amount based on the expected costs for all services provided for each clinically defined episode of care (e.g., hip replacement, cholecystectomy), irrespective of the ultimate cost. Payment is then distributed to all the health care providers involved in the care of the patient for that specific episode. This payment model incentivizes cost-effective provision of care and increases accountability and transparency through reporting of quality metrics. Risks include provision of substandard care as a method of cost reduction. For example, physicians may be pressured to prematurely discharge patients from the hospital because the compensation received for each admission does not increase with a prolonged duration of hospital stay.
questions.hint: This payment model encourages the cost-effective provision of care.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to a free clinic because of a 2-year history of a growing mass on his back. It is occasionally painful and has discharged malodorous cheeselike material. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He has been unemployed for the past 9 months, and his only source of income comes from unemployment benefits. Examination shows a 1.4-cm, nontender, mobile nodule with a central punctum. A diagnosis of an epidermal inclusion cyst is made, and the patient is recommended to undergo surgical excision. The physician notes that the patient has no health insurance. Which of the following health insurance plans is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Health maintenance organization
Point of service
Exclusive provider organization
Medicare
Preferred provider organization
Medicaid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A health maintenance organization (HMO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees must choose from to obtain health care. No coverage is provided for out-of-network doctors, specialists, or hospitals, except in an emergency. Although the costs of an HMO plan are often low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

B) INCORRECT:

A point of service (POS) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees can choose from to obtain health care. Enrollees have coverage for out-of-network providers, and a referral is needed from the primary care physician to see a specialist. Although the costs of in-network care in a POS plan can be low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

C) INCORRECT:

An exclusive provider organization (EPO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees must choose from to get health care. No coverage is provided for out-of-network doctors, specialists, or hospitals, except in an emergency. Enrollees can be seen in-network without a referral from a primary care physician. Although member costs of an EPO plan are often low, this patient is eligible for another insurance program that can cover all of his medical costs because he is unemployed.

D) INCORRECT:

Medicare is government-funded health insurance that consists of 4 parts, each of which provide coverage for different services. To be eligible for Medicare, patients must meet one of three criteria: be ≥ 65 years old, have end-stage renal failure or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or have permanent disabilities (regardless of age). This patient does not meet any of the criteria for Medicare coverage.

E) INCORRECT:

A preferred provider organization (PPO) plan consists of a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals that enrollees can choose from to get health care. PPO enrollees also have coverage for out-of-network providers and can see specialists without a referral from a primary care physician. PPO plans often have high member costs, so a PPO would not be the most appropriate insurance plan for this uninsured patient.

F) CORRECT:

Medicaid is a government-funded health insurance plan that provides comprehensive coverage for hospital care, laboratory tests, diagnostic tests, and doctors visits. To be eligible for Medicaid, patients must be under 65 years of age and meet the income eligibility based on the modified adjusted gross income (MAGI) threshold set by the state's health insurance marketplace. Federal eligibility also extends to pregnant women, children, and individuals receiving supplemental security income. Those who are eligible for Medicaid must be US citizens (or qualify in other ways, e.g., lawful permanent residents) and live in the same state where Medicaid is received. Individual states have the additional option to modify eligibility.
questions.hint: This patient's unemployment status makes him eligible for this health insurance program.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for glycemic control. She recently emigrated from Russia. She does not speak English and asks her bilingual adult daughter to translate. Her hemoglobin A1C is 9.1%. A physician notices that the average hemoglobin A1C of patients with diabetes mellitus and limited English proficiency in the hospital is significantly higher when compared to patients proficient in English. The hospital conducts an inpatient study, which finds a statistically significant correlation between scores on a standardized verbal English proficiency test and scores on standardized medication adherence scales and patient-physician concordance scales. Based on the results of a subsequent root cause analysis, the hospital management renegotiates health care payment contracts with their insurance provider to allow for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services. This intervention best addresses which of the following barriers to high-quality health care?

choices.text: Information bias
Distributive injustice
Health illiteracy
Identity devaluation
Availability heuristic

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Information bias is a systemic research error caused by inconsistencies in measurement and/or classification between sample groups. This bias can be corrected by using standardized data collection techniques. Information bias is not a barrier to high-quality health care in this scenario, and it cannot be addressed by allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services.

B) CORRECT:

Distributive injustice, a result of inequitable access to care, is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP are at high risk of experiencing distributive injustice, which can cause patient-physician discordance and medication nonadherence, as seen here. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services facilitates equitable access to care, which contributes to the correction of distributive injustice.

C) INCORRECT:

Health illiteracy, which is primarily due to the complexity of health care information and health care systems, is a barrier to high-quality health care but is distinct from LEP. Patients of all ethnicities, languages, and cultures can be affected by health illiteracy. Conversely, a patient with LEP can have a high level of health literacy in their native language. The use of professional medical interpreter services helps patients with LEP to receive information from health care providers in their native language but it does not address health illiteracy per se since the translated information can still be complex. Simplifying information (e.g., avoiding technical medical jargon, breaking down instructions into simple steps) is an intervention to improve health literacy.

D) INCORRECT:

Identity devaluation (i.e., relational injustice) is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP may experience identity devaluation due to incorrect assumptions by caregivers (e.g., about the patient's intelligence) or broader cultural incongruities. Identity devaluation can be corrected by systemic changes that increase intercultural understanding, such as hiring more bilingual physicians. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services does not increase intercultural understanding per se because it does not improve health care providers' intercultural competence.

E) INCORRECT:

The availability heuristic, a type of cognitive bias, is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. Availability heuristics can be a barrier to high-quality health care because they result in diagnostic errors by health care providers and in medication nonadherence by patients. The availability heuristic is unrelated to a patient's English proficiency, and allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services will not address this cognitive bias.
questions.hint: The intervention (i.e., resource allocation) for patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) was undertaken by the hospital to prevent poor health outcomes as a result of inequitable access to care.

questions.text: The head of a hospital renegotiates their contract with an insurance company for the reimbursement of all services provided to patients undergoing daycare surgery. Under the new contract, each service that is provided to the patient will be codified using an established classification code and the hospital will be reimbursed for each unbundled service. Prices for each individual service will be negotiated in advance and listed in schedules, and payments will be issued after the services are provided. The newly negotiated payment model is most likely to have which of the following effects on healthcare measures at the hospital?

choices.text: Decrease in the frequency of preventable adverse events
Increase in referral rates for nonsurgical management
Increase in the number of elective laparoscopic procedures
Decrease in the use of diagnostic radiology services

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the FFS model, the hospital is reimbursed for each service provided, regardless of performance and/or outcome. A decrease in the number of preventable adverse events would not be the most likely effect of the implementation of an FFS system because such a model does not provide any incentives for decreasing error rates. On the contrary, hospitals with the FFS model tend not to implement services that improve quality of care if they do not directly generate income (e.g., training staff) and are reimbursed for each subsequent service made necessary by an error.

B) INCORRECT:

The FFS model, which rewards activity rather than efficient use of resources and disincentivizes care coordination, would most likely lead to a decrease rather than an increase in referral for nonsurgical management.

C) CORRECT:

The FFS model provides reimbursements for each unbundled health care service provided, rewarding activity rather than efficient use of resources. This can lead to overutilization of health care services, as evidenced, for example, by an increase in the number of elective surgeries. Furthermore, the FFS model does not reward performance, good outcomes, and/or coordination of services. Together, these effects lead to healthcare fragmentation and increased health care expenditures. Nevertheless, the FFS model is the dominant payment model in the US. Advantages of this model include price transparency, large revenues, and a decrease in administrative overhead expenditure.

Alternatives to the FFS model include the capitation model, the bundled payment model, and the pay-for-performance model. All of these models aim to overcome the disadvantages of the traditional FFS model (e.g., inefficient utilization of resources) but are not without their own disadvantages (e.g., increased overhead expenditure with the pay-for-performance model).

D) INCORRECT:

In the FFS model, the health care provider is reimbursed for each service provided rather than for the treatment of a patient’s condition over the entire care cycle. Reimbursement for each individual service regardless of the previous results obtained by other providers tends to foster duplication, lack of coordination, and lack of accountability. This would lead to an increase rather than a decrease in the use of diagnostic radiology services.
questions.hint: This hospital wants to implement a payment model for its daycare surgery patients in which the health care organization is reimbursed for each service provided (e.g., each consultation, laboratory study, imaging study). Such a model is called a fee-for-service (FFS) payment model.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon?

choices.text: Defer knee surgery until a request for reimbursement is approved by the HMO
Inform the patient that she has to pay out of pocket because HMOs do not cover elective orthopedic surgeries
Perform the knee surgery and ask the primary care physician to submit a pre-claim review to the HMO
Perform the knee surgery and then submit a reimbursement claim to the HMO
Ask the patient to seek approval from the HMO for reimbursement prior to surgery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prior authorization (PA) is a process used by health insurance companies to evaluate the medical necessity and cost of medications, tests, and treatments in order to approve coverage before they are provided to the patient. Health insurance companies usually require PA for elective and expensive interventions that have lower-cost alternatives (e.g., arthroplasty). PA is obtained to ensure that the health insurance company will cover the requested care, protecting patients from financial liability. If a health care provider is in-network, they are responsible for determining whether an intervention needs PA and for submitting the request form to the health insurance company. Treatment should only be provided after the health insurance company has reviewed and approved the request.

Many health care providers have called for reforming of the PA process because of its detrimental impact on patient care. PAs are widely considered to be a time-consuming administrative burden that can result in delays in care and adverse clinical outcomes. Submitting requests electronically can help reduce administrative time and speed up the process of obtaining PA.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with HMOs must pay out of pocket for services by out-of-network providers. However, this patient's surgeon is in-network, and HMOs cover elective orthopedic surgeries that are considered medically necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

A pre-claim review requests provisional confirmation of coverage after treatment but before the submission of a final claim for payment. Because total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage by the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is preferred. In addition, the treating physician is responsible for submitting a pre-claim review.

D) INCORRECT:

Submitting a reimbursement claim to the HMO after treatment can be considered in emergency situations. However, because a total knee arthroplasty is an expensive, elective procedure with lower-cost alternatives, coverage from the insurance company is not guaranteed. To avoid placing a financial burden on the patient, another action is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Approval from the HMO is required prior to certain types of interventions, especially expensive treatments and those with lower-cost alternatives (e.g., total knee arthroplasty). However, the patient is not responsible for seeking approval for treatments given by in-network providers.
questions.hint: This strategy, which is also considered when prescribing biological immunosuppressants, aims to control costs and provide only the necessary care.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension, stroke with residual right hemiparesis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and previously undiagnosed type 2 diabetes is being discharged home after a 4-day hospitalization for a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state and a urinary tract infection. He is being started on three new medications at home (insulin glargine, metformin, and lisinopril), and his physical therapist recommends that he continue a supervised exercise program three times per week.
He lives alone, uses a wheelchair for mobility, and rarely leaves home; when he does, he requires specialized transportation and equipment. His home has been modified to allow him to live there safely, and his neighbors and friends assist with grocery shopping, meal preparation, and bathing.
Which one of the following criteria must this patient meet to be eligible for home health care under Medicare?

choices.text: Hospitalization for ≥3 days
Physical therapy evaluation
Homebound status
New diagnosis of diabetes
Requirement for insulin injections

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the initial purpose of home health care was to facilitate the transition from hospital to home, the requirement for recent hospitalization was eliminated in 1980; thus, a hospital stay of ≥3 days is not needed to qualify for home health services.

B) INCORRECT:

A physical therapy (PT) evaluation is not required to qualify for home health services, although such an evaluation is frequently conducted to help establish a PT care plan. If indicated, continued PT at home is a covered benefit for Medicare beneficiaries who are homebound.

C) CORRECT:

To be eligible for Medicare coverage of home health services, including visiting-nurse services, individuals must (1) be considered homebound, (2) be under the care of a physician who assesses them in a face-to-face or telehealth visit within 90 days before the start of services and periodically reviews their care plan, and (3) have a need for skilled-nursing care, physical therapy, or speech and language pathology services.

According to Medicare, patients are considered homebound if they meet both of the following criteria:

• They have a medical contraindication to leaving home, or they have an illness or injury that prevents them from leaving home without a supportive device, special transportation, or personal assistance.
• They are typically unable to leave home — and when they do, it requires considerable and taxing effort.

Approximately 6% of older adults in the U.S are considered homebound at any given time, and this status is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. In one study of older adults, those who were homebound were twice as likely to die during a 2-year period as those who were not homebound, even after accounting for sociodemographic factors, comorbidities, and functional status. Notably, homebound status is a highly dynamic state: in a study of newly homebound older adults, 40% recovered enough within the first year to no longer meet homebound criteria, although many did eventually return to homebound status by year 6.

Key learning point: Home health services are covered by Medicare only if the patient meets eligibility criteria for being homebound.

D) INCORRECT:

A new diagnosis of diabetes would present a substantial challenge for many older adults but would not alone merit approval by Medicare for visiting-nurse services.

E) INCORRECT:

A new requirement for insulin injections would present a substantial challenge for many older adults but would not alone merit approval by Medicare for visiting-nurse services.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man with coronary artery disease, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, osteoarthritis, and type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up after being hospitalized for an exacerbation of heart failure. It was his third hospitalization for heart failure in the past 4 months.
Before being discharged home from the hospital, he was evaluated by the inpatient geriatric service and a physical therapist. He was found to be independent in his activities of daily living (bathing, toileting, dressing, and grooming). He also cooks his own meals, does his own grocery shopping, and has been responsible for taking his medications. He walks with a cane. He has retired from driving because of poor vision, and his son accompanies him to medical appointments, including today’s visit.
He reports no symptoms at today’s visit, and his weight has been stable since discharge. His physical examination is unremarkable, and he appears euvolemic on examination.
Which one of the following interventions is best for preventing all-cause hospital readmissions in this patient?

choices.text: Enroll him in a remote telehealth monitoring program with daily tracking of weight and other vital signs
Initiate a multidisciplinary intervention that includes visits to his home
Enroll him in a program with frequent postdischarge telephone calls to assess his clinical condition and provide support
Schedule an appointment for him to meet with a pharmacist to discuss his medications
Admit him to a skilled nursing facility

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enrolling patients in a remote telemonitoring program may be a helpful intervention, but it is not by itself associated with a reduced risk for all-cause hospital readmission.

B) CORRECT:

Given this patient’s recent hospitalizations for heart failure, he is at high risk for readmission, and interventions should be implemented to avoid this. In a systematic review and meta-analysis of 53 clinical trials conducted among older adults discharged from the hospital with heart failure, three interventions were effective in reducing all-cause hospital readmissions:

• Nurse home visits
• Nurse case management (a combination of nurse home visits and structured telephone support)
• Disease-management clinics

In this particular case, the patient meets Medicare homebound criteria (by virtue of needing assistance from both another person and a device to leave his home) and is thus eligible for visiting-nurse services. The clinician could therefore refer him to a visiting-nurse program that could provide home visits, medication management and education, and home physical and occupational therapy, among other skilled services, if indicated.

Although studies have shown a reduction in readmissions with improved patient communication at discharge for patients with respiratory illnesses, these findings do not extend to patients with primary cardiac disease.

Key learning point: Prevention of hospital readmission in a functionally independent older adult may be best accomplished through a multidisciplinary intervention that includes visits to their home.

C) INCORRECT:

Scheduling frequent postdischarge telephone calls to assess patients’ clinical condition may be a helpful intervention, but it is not by itself associated with a reduced risk for all-cause hospital readmission.

D) INCORRECT:

Scheduling appointments for patients to meet with pharmacists may be a helpful intervention, but it is not by itself associated with a reduced risk for all-cause hospital readmission.

E) INCORRECT:

A functionally independent patient who can perform all activities of daily living and manage their household is not likely to qualify for admission to a skilled nursing facility (SNF). Medicare covers an SNF stay only when a patient needs inpatient care from professional personnel such as registered nurses, licensed practical nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, or audiologists. This patient does not need this type of support at this time.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents for follow-up 3 days after an emergency department visit in which he was diagnosed with a deep-vein thrombosis in his left lower extremity. During that visit, he was given the direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) apixaban and then discharged home after a period of observation. No predisposing or reversible risk factors were found.
Today, he reports that when he went to his local pharmacy to fill the prescription to continue apixaban, he was informed that the drug is not covered by his insurance and would cost $230 per month. He was able to pay for one week’s supply out of pocket and then called his insurance company, which advised him that his policy would only cover DOACs at a high tier, with copays ranging from $200 to $500 per month. The insurer suggested he switch to warfarin, which would be covered with a $5 monthly copay.
You advise the patient that he should receive anticoagulation therapy for 3 to 6 months, and you discuss the monitoring requirements and dietary restrictions with warfarin therapy. The patient says that adherence would be difficult for him: he reports traveling a lot for work, which would limit his food options and impede reliable monitoring of his international normalized ratio (INR). His preference is to stay on apixaban because he has tolerated it well and finds it easy to take, but he does not think he can afford to pay any more than $50 per month for this medication.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Prescribe warfarin, and advise the patient to get workplace accommodations for monitoring
Refer the patient to the apixaban manufacturer’s website, which offers a free 30-day trial and $10 copay options
Refer the patient for an inferior vena cava filter, which is covered by the patient’s insurance with a $250 copay
Prescribe 30 days of apixaban, and switch to warfarin for the remaining 5 months
Prescribe enoxaparin injections, which would cost $80 per month

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Warfarin would be an acceptable second choice in this scenario for all or part of the treatment course if appropriate accommodations could be made to allow for the required monitoring. The patient says that adherence to warfarin would be difficult for him and his preference is to stay on apixaban. Moreover, the standard of care for deep-vein thrombosis is initiation of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which have several advantages over older medications such as warfarin such as a lower risk of bleeding and recurrent thrombosis. When there is an available medication that is clearly better than cheaper alternatives, the initial approach should be to explore options that could make the preferred treatment more affordable.

B) CORRECT:

The standard of care for deep-vein thrombosis is initiation of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which have several advantages over older medications such as warfarin but can be prohibitively expensive for some patients. questions.text:
A group of clinicians at a primary care clinic noticed that many of their patients with hypertension did not seem to have adequate blood pressure (BP) control, so they launched a quality improvement project to identify the causes and propose solutions. As part of the project, they reviewed the medical charts of patients with hypertension and extracted BP readings as well as other medical and sociodemographic information.
Their analysis revealed that patients with public insurance had much higher BP readings than patients with private insurance. Patients with public insurance also had a higher prevalence of untreated or poorly controlled comorbid conditions (e.g., diabetes and heart disease) and a lower rate of referral to specialists to evaluate these conditions.
Which one of the following explanations for these findings is most plausible?

choices.text: Private insurance is likely to provide more-accurate home BP monitors than public insurance.
Patients with public insurance are less likely to be truthful about their medication adherence than those with private insurance.
Public insurance only pays for less effective generic medications.
Lower-income patients with public insurance often have less access to healthy food choices.
Patients with public insurance are more likely to belong to racial groups that have a genetic predisposition to severe hypertension.

A) INCORRECT:

Access to BP monitors is an unlikely source of the inequity described in this case; Studies have found that patients with public insurance have adequate access to health care and, in fact, have more clinic visits on average than patients with private insurance; frequent, accurate BP measurements are unlikely to have as much effect on a patient’s health as access to a healthy diet and a good environment for exercise.

B) INCORRECT:

When health disparities occur, overt or hidden biases on the part of providers can lead to incorrect assumptions about a patient’s adherence to care, their knowledge of their condition and treatment, and their likelihood of being up-front with the clinician about their adherence to therapy. Instead, focusing on the social determinants of health can help identify systemic issues that may be remedied to help improve outcomes. Studies have found that patients with public insurance have adequate access to health care and, in fact, have more clinic visits on average than patients with private insurance.

Although generic medications are often preferred by insurance companies (both public and private) because of their lower cost, this preference is not expected to affect blood pressure outcomes since generic medications are as effective as brand-name ones.

D) CORRECT:

Health disparities based on race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, gender identity, sexual orientation, and language are common. In many cases, the cause of the disparities involves social determinants of health that are beyond the control of individual patients and providers. When health disparities occur, overt or hidden biases on the part of providers can lead to incorrect assumptions about a patient’s adherence to care, their knowledge of their condition and treatment, and their likelihood of being up-front with the clinician about their adherence to therapy. Studies have found that patients with public insurance have adequate access to health care and, in fact, have more clinic visits on average than patients with private insurance; they also have, on average, a higher number of medications prescribed.

Although the racial composition of patients with public insurance may differ from the racial composition of those with private insurance, there is no proven biologic basis for racial classification and no evidence to support a racially based genetic predisposition to severe hypertension.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic renal insufficiency is being discharged after hospitalization for an exacerbation of heart failure. His presenting symptoms of orthopnea and peripheral edema have responded well to several days of diuretic therapy. A previous echocardiogram, performed when the patient was euvolemic, showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%. The patient's medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, carvedilol, spironolactone, and furosemide. He lives with his son and has adequate financial support. His son has agreed to obtain a pill box from the pharmacy and to monitor his father's medication and dietary adherence. Which of the following steps before discharge would most effectively reduce this patient’s risk of readmission?

choices.text: Arrange a follow-up appointment with the primary care provider
Write the discharge summary in simple jargon-free language
Link inpatient and outpatient medications electronically
Provide the patient a phone number to call in case of difficulties

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Readmissions can be reduced effectively by focusing on several areas of the discharge process. Before discharge, a follow-up appointment should be arranged with the patient's primary care provider. Simply alerting the patient’s primary care provider about discharge is not as effective as actually ensuring that the patient has appropriate follow-up appointments in place. In addition, a specific staff member should be assigned the responsibility of performing medication reconciliation, education on medication use, and follow-up on laboratory results that are still pending. Within 2–3 days of discharge, an electronic discharge summary should be sent to the patient’s primary care provider and a postdischarge follow-up phone call should happen. This phone call supports continuity of care until the patient's appointment with their primary care provider and helps address issues during this period that may increase the risk of readmission. A visiting nurse program offering skilled services (e.g., physical therapy, medication management) through home visits can also help reduce the risk of readmission. Patients qualify for Medicare-covered visiting nurse services if they meet the homebound criteria, i.e., requiring assistance from both another person and a device to leave their home.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include a section that provides patient instructions and plans for follow-up care in easy-to-understand language. Additionally, the discharge summary is also intended to inform the patient's primary care provider, so writing the entire discharge summary in jargon-free language may not be feasible.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation, a key part of the discharge process, can help decrease the risk of readmissions. Linking an individual's inpatient and outpatient medications through an integrated electronic health record system can make medication reconciliation easier but this intervention does not by itself complete the medication reconciliation process.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include contact information of the attending physician and consulting services involved in the patient's care to allow the patient or their primary health care provider to reach out in case of postdischarge care difficulties. However, patients may be hesitant to initiate contact, and relying on this passive system places the responsibility for follow-up on the patient. Instead, actively calling the patient at home about postdischarge needs within 2–3 days of discharge is part of effective discharge programs.
questions.hint: Common causes for hospital readmission include complications or exacerbations of existing health conditions, inadequate management after discharge, and posthospital syndrome. Patients with advanced heart failure have some of the highest rates of hospital readmission.
